learning_outcomes.description: Define a problem, state a hypothesis and propose a process for the investigation of the problem.
Design and implement a research project, analyse and interpret data, discuss results and draw relevant conclusions.
Produce a research report in the form of a potential journal article.
Deliver an oral presentation on a defined topic.
Demonstrate professional behaviour in the context of the researchable topic, in consultation with the supervisory team

assessments.task_description:
A written assessment whose aim is to provide students with the tools to more effectively manage their project as well as give the opportunity for a personal reflection. This will be marked by your primary supervisor.

The purpose of this 4-part mid-project assessment is to a) articulate your research problem early on b) encourage conceptual organisation c) promote professional reflection on complex issues around supervision, communication and project management d) foster the use of ubiquitous project management tools such as mind maps and GANTT charts and e) enable responsible use of generative AI.

N.B. You will not be penalised if your research strategy changes after this assessment piece is submitted. Indeed, adaptation, pivots and change are acknowledged as a normal and healthy part of research science. This is intended to be a constructive process – not a punitive one.

The assessment will a) introduce you to tools and processes that help scientists meet deadlines without undue stress and time pressure but also b) support productive change, should the evidence indicate to you and your team that change is required.

You are given 4 tasks to complete:

·      Proposal / strategy document (1 page)

·      Mind map (1 page)

·      GANTT chart (1 page)

·      Professional reflection and questionnaire (there are 13 questions to guide your reflection).

You are encouraged to develop the first three of these in consultation with your project supervisor WITHOUT recourse to AI.

Once you have mature drafts of all three in place you are then encouraged to use a generative AI system of your choice for provision of feedback and suggestions for improvement.

As part of your professional reflection, you will then be asked to make specific comments on the utility of generative AI in the context of these 3 activities.

You are encouraged to develop your personal reflection in consultation with your supervisor. You MUST NOT use generative AI to help you write your personal reflection.

The assessment document available on BB includes some links to supporting Freeware.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing the components of the assessment task indicated above. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. 

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. 

The use of AI and / or MT must be acknowledged using a statement recorded on the coversheet. The statement must contain a description of the AI system that has been engaged and detail around the nature of use. Please see assessment guidelines in the blackboard course site for specific instructions.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You must submit your Assessment task, in Blackboard, via the Turnitin link by the submission deadline. You should also retain an electronic copy of every piece of assessment you submit.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
The research project report is to be presented in the form of a scientific manuscript potentially suitable for publication in a professional journal.

The exact length and structure of your report may vary across disciplines – please seek specific advice from your supervisor regarding your interpretation of these guidelines.

Broadly speaking, we anticipate the report consisting of a title, abstract (< 300 words), introduction / background / literature review (< 600 words for science reports, but a much longer, more comprehensive literature review for social science and agribusiness reports), methodology including statistical analysis (< 2000 words), results (< 2000 words), discussion (< 1500 words), conclusions (< 200 words) and references.

In general concision is encouraged, the upper word count limits are to be considered guidelines only and represent a conversation starter for discussion with your supervisor.

Two independent markers who specialise in your area of research will grade your work. The average of your marks from both markers will be used as your grade. In the event that there is a difference of more than 10 points between markers your report will be sent to an independent marker and a decision made which may involve taking the average of the 3 marks.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use Artificial Intelligence (AI) and/or Machine Translation (MT) tools, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which AI or MT will provide only limited support and guidance. 

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. 

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools. 

The use of AI and / or MT must be acknowledged using a statement recorded on the coversheet. The statement must contain a description of the AI system that has been engaged and detail around the nature of use. Please see assessment guidelines in the blackboard course site for specific instructions.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Students should submit either a word or pdf file via Turnitin on the course Blackboard site, via the relevant submission links by the submission deadline. You should also retain an electronic copy of every piece of assessment you submit. Students will need to submit their Report twice (the same version) because there will be 2 markers. Therefore, please allow sufficient time on the due date to submit it twice.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
25/05/2026 - 29/05/2026

Seminars will occur over the 2-days as indicated in the timetable. Should student numbers be greater than the scheduled time, an additional day may be scheduled into the timetable, following confirmation of total number of students enrolled in the AGRC-code research project courses.
assessments.task_description:
Students are required to give a 5 minute live 'in person' oral presentation at a student conference in Week 13. External students will attend and present live via Zoom. Presentations will be marked by 2 examiners, with the averages of these two marks to be used as the final assessment mark.

There will be 3 minutes allocated for questions.

Students should use appropriate visual aids (e.g. PowerPoint Slides) based on the UQ template to assist your presentation. 

Marks will be deducted for presentations that go over the allotted time.

Presentation marking criteria, plus an example of presentation slides and a presentation template are available in the course Blackboard site. 

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use Artificial Intelligence (AI) and/or Machine Translation (MT) tools, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which AI or MT will provide only limited support and guidance. 

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. 

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools. 

The use of AI and / or MT must be acknowledged using a statement recorded on one of your Powerpoint (or similar) slides. The statement must contain a description of the AI system that has been engaged and detail around the nature of use. Please see assessment guidelines in the blackboard course site for specific instructions.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Students will deliver a live 5 minute oral presentation in a conference style setting. Some time will be set aside for questions.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Performance as determined by project supervisor
assessments.category: Participation/ Student contribution, Practical/ Demonstration, Project
assessments.task_description:
Your academic supervisor will assess your overall performance through the life cycle of your research project.

'Performance' here includes the indicators below that your supervisor deems of relevance to your circumstances:

1) Evidence of planning.

2) Evidence of time management.

3) Evidence of punctuality.

4) Evidence of resourcefulness.

5) Evidence of independent thought and creativity.

6) Evidence of 'managing up' well.

7) Evidence of positive interactions with peers, such as laboratory colleagues, if applicable.

8) Evidence of determination, and other positive temperamental characteristics, in overcoming challenges.

9) Evidence of strong inter-personal communication.

10) Evidence of integrity and ethical awareness.

11) Evidence for record keeping

12) Evidence for house keeping.
assessments.submission_guidelines: This item is submitted by the student's Supervisor. A student is not responsible for submitting this task.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: As this assessment is completed by the Supervisor in conjunction with Course staff, students will not receive late penalties for this assessment item.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

Independent Project

This course is based on independent study under the supervision of an academic staff member.
learning_activities.topic_description: Independent Project This course is based on independent study under the supervision of an academic staff member.

learning_activities.topic:
Research Project Writing Workshops

The School provides students a series of optional academic and project writing workshops throughout the semester, when able. Students are strongly encouraged to attend these sessions and/or other writing support options, which are designed to assist in research project writing.

Sub-activity: Research Project Writing Workshop Series or Recordings - Suresh Krishnasamy
